The **seventh series** of _[The Great British Bake
Off](/wiki/The_Great_British_Bake_Off "The Great British Bake Off")_ aired
from 24 August 2016, with twelve contestants competing to be crowned the
series 7 winner.[1][2]

This series was the last to be broadcast on [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC
One"), as the production company Love Productions opted to move the show to
[Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4").[3] It was also the last series on
the show for Sue Perkins and Mel Giedroyc, as they decided to leave as
presenters of the show.[4] It is also the last series of the show to feature
Mary Berry as a judge.[5] This series was won by Candice Brown, with Andrew
Smyth and Jane Beedle finishing as runners-up.

### Episode 1:
Cake[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Episode 1: Cake")]

For the first challenge, the bakers were given two hours to make a drizzle
cake, the brief being that the cake be moist and well permeated with the
drizzle. For the technical challenge, the bakers were instructed to make
Mary's recipe for twelve [jaffa cakes](/wiki/Jaffa_Cakes "Jaffa Cakes"). The
recipe used a whipped fatless sponge, orange jelly and tempered chocolate with
a design of sorts. For the final challenge, the bakers were instructed to make
a mirror glaze cake. The cake had to have a genoise sponge and have a very
shiny, mirror-like top, covering the cake entirely.

technique\)") Cake)

### Episode 2:
Biscuits[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Episode 2: Biscuits")]

For the Signature Challenge, the bakers were given two and a half hours to
make 24 iced biscuits (cookies). The biscuits had to be crisp and uniform.
[Viennese Whirls](/wiki/Viennese_Whirls "Viennese Whirls") were set as the
technical challenge. To be completed in an hour and a half, they had to be
filled with buttercream and jam, and had have a defined shape. For the
showstopper, a gingerbread scene was set as the challenge, the only brief
being it that it had to be 30 cm high, and contain eight characters or
objects. The bakers had four hours for this challenge.

Host Sue Perkins did not appear in the episode.[24][25]

(24 [Iced](/wiki/Icing_\(food\) "Icing \(food\)") Biscuits) | Technical

### Episode 3:
Bread[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Episode 3: Bread")]

For the bakers' first challenge, they had to make a chocolate loaf in two and
a half hours. The loaf had to contain chocolate in some form, whether it be
cocoa powder or actual pieces of chocolate. For the technical challenge, the
bakers were required to make twelve [Dampfnudel](/wiki/Dampfnudel
"Dampfnudel"), a recipe Paul called "notoriously difficult". In two hours, the
bakers had to make twelve steamed bread rolls with two types of sauce. A
savoury plaited (braided) centrepiece was set as the showstopper. In four
hours, bakers had to make a centrepiece using at least three flours.

### Episode 4:

"Edit section: Episode 4: Batter")]

"Yorkshire pudding"), which involved the standard recipe filled with a variety
of ingredients and flavours. The technical challenge was to make 12 heart-
shaped "lace" [pancakes](/wiki/Pancake "Pancake"), which required the bakers
to draw a heart-shaped design with the batter. The showstopper challenge was
to make 36 [churros](/wiki/Churro "Churro").[26]

[filo](/wiki/Filo "Filo")  _[amuse-bouche](/wiki/Amuse-bouche "Amuse-bouche")_
; 24 with a savoury filling and 24 with a sweet filling.

### Episode 6:
Botanical[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Episode 6: Botanical")]

In the signature, the seven remaining bakers were asked to create a meringue
pie containing citrus fruit, such as orange, grapefruits and lemons. In the
technical, the contestants had to create two leaf-shaped herb
[fougasses](/wiki/Fougasse_\(bread\) "Fougasse \(bread\)"). In the
showstopper, the contestants were asked to create a three-tier cake with a
flower theme. All the tiers could be the same flavour, or each one a different
flavour, and the cakes could be decorated with flowers.

(Citrus [Meringue](/wiki/Meringue "Meringue") Pie) | Technical

(Three-Tier Flower Cake)

### Episode 7:
Desserts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Episode 7: Desserts")]

The Signature challenge required the bakers to make a family-sized
[roulade](/wiki/Swiss_roll "Swiss roll"). The judges were looking for a light
sponge cake, even layers of filling, and a clean swirl. The technical
challenge was for a Marjolaine or _[dacquoise](/wiki/Dacquoise "Dacquoise")_ ,
an unusual layered cake made with meringue, decorated with ganache and nuts.
The showstopper challenge tasked the bakers with making 24 mini
[mousse](/wiki/Mousse "Mousse") cakes in two flavours (12 of each).[27][28]

Baker | Signature  
(Family-Sized [Roulade](/wiki/Swiss_roll "Swiss roll")) | Technical  
([Marjolaine](/wiki/Dacquoise "Dacquoise")) | Showstopper  
(24 Mini [Mousse](/wiki/Mousse "Mousse") Cakes)  
---|---|---|---  
Andrew | Tropical Holiday Roulade | 1st | Childhood Ice Cream Mousse Cakes

Jane | Chocolate and Hazelnut Roulade | 4th | Chocolate, Coffee and Vanilla [Joconde Cake](/wiki/Opera_cake "Opera cake")s and Blackcurrant and Vanilla Ombré [Mousse](/wiki/Mousse "Mousse")s  
Selasi | Summer Picnic Roulade | 6th | Lemon, Strawberry and Passionfruit and Chocolate and Mint Mini Mousse Cakes  
Tom | Millionaire's Roulade | 5th | Hipster Picnic  
  
### Episode 8:
Tudor[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Episode 8: Tudor")]

Week eight featured the show's first [Tudor](/wiki/Tudor_period "Tudor
period") theme, featuring food common in the 16th century. During the
signature challenge, the five remaining bakers were asked to bake a shaped pie
with Tudor flavours. The pie could be any type of pastry and they could use
whichever fillings they wanted. In the technical, the contestants were asked
to produce a dozen [jumbles](/wiki/Jumble_\(cookie\) "Jumble \(cookie\)") –
six [knot balls](/wiki/Monkey%27s_fist "Monkey's fist") and six [Celtic
knots](/wiki/Triquetra "Triquetra"). In the showstopper challenge, the
contestants were asked to bake a marchpane ([marzipan](/wiki/Marzipan
"Marzipan")) cake in a [three-dimensional](/wiki/Three-dimensional_space
"Three-dimensional space") shape. However, all of the cakes had to be Tudor-
themed.[29]

Baker | Signature  
(Shaped [Savoury Pies](/wiki/Meat_pie "Meat pie")) | Technical  
(12 [Jumbles](/wiki/Jumble_\(cookie\) "Jumble \(cookie\)")) | Showstopper  
(3D [Marchpane](/wiki/Marchpane "Marchpane") Cake)  
---|---|---|---  
Andrew | [Da Vinci](/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci "Leonardo da Vinci") Inspired Geared Pies | 2nd | Jousting Knights Marchpane  
Benjamina | Mexican Adventure | 4th | Tudor Garden  
Candice | Cheesy Cheeky Fish Pies | 1st | Peacock  
Jane | [Tudor Rose](/wiki/Tudor_Rose "Tudor Rose") Pies | 5th | Swans  
Selasi | Bouquet of Flowers | 3rd | Fruity Tudor Marchpane  
  
### Episode 9: Pâtisserie (semi-
final)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Episode 9: Pâtisserie \(semi-final\)")]

The first task for [pastry](/wiki/Pastry "Pastry") or
[pâtisserie](/wiki/P%C3%A2tisserie "Pâtisserie") week required the remaining
four contestants to bake 24 [palmiers](/wiki/Palmier "Palmier"), with two
different savoury fillings and shapes. The technical challenge was to make a
[Savarin](/wiki/Rum_baba#Savarin "Rum baba"), a liqueur-soaked yeast cake,
which none of the contestants had made before. The final challenge was to make
36 [fondant fancies](/wiki/Fondant_Fancy "Fondant Fancy").[30][31]

(24 savoury [palmiers](/wiki/Palmier "Palmier")) | Technical

### Episode 10: Royal picnic
(final)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Episode 10: Royal picnic \(final\)")]

In the final signature challenge, the bakers had to make a filled meringue
crown, which had to contain at least three layers of meringue, in three hours.
In the technical, the judges decided to make a familiar bake challenging: the
bakers had to make a Victoria sandwich, with no recipe or method given, in 90
minutes. The final showstopper involved the largest number of bakes ever
requested in a challenge. The bakers were given five hours to make a picnic
fit for the Queen, including one chocolate celebration cake, 12 sausage rolls,
12 mini [quiches](/wiki/Quiche "Quiche"), 12 savoury [scones](/wiki/Scones
"Scones") and 12 fruit and custard tarts.[32][33]

Baker | Signature  
(Meringue crowns) | Technical  
([Victoria sandwich](/wiki/Sponge_cake#Victoria_sponge "Sponge cake") with no recipe) | Showstopper  
(Picnics)  
---|---|---|---  
Andrew | Crunchy Caramel Cassis Crown | 1st | Family and Friends' Favourites Picnic  
Candice | Queen Victoria's Mango and Strawberry Crown | 2nd | Picnic for Pearly Kings and Queens  
Jane | Red, White and Blue Meringue Crown | 3rd | Family Favourites Feast  
  
## Christmas
specials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Christmas specials")]

The Masterclass episodes were replaced by two Christmas specials, which
featured eight contestants from the series 2–5. The two Christmas specials
were the last to be aired on BBC before the channel move, and thus featured
the last appearances of hosts [Mel Giedroyc](/wiki/Mel_Giedroyc "Mel
Giedroyc") and [Sue Perkins](/wiki/Sue_Perkins "Sue Perkins") and judge [Mary
Berry](/wiki/Mary_Berry_\(food_writer\) "Mary Berry \(food writer\)"). Judge
[Paul Hollywood](/wiki/Paul_Hollywood "Paul Hollywood") would then followed
the channel move.[34]

The first Christmas special featured Mary-Anne Boermans (Series 2), Cathryn
Dresser (Series 3), [Ali Imdad](/wiki/Ali_Imdad "Ali Imdad") (Series 4) and
Norman Calder (Series 5). The competition was won by Mary-Anne Boermans. The
second Christmas special featured Janet Basu (Series 2), [James
Morton](/wiki/James_Morton_\(baker\) "James Morton \(baker\)") (Series 3),
Howard Middleton (Series 4) and Chetna Makan (Series 5). The competition was
won by Chetna Makan.

### Episode
1[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Episode 1")]

The signature challenge required the bakers to create 2 batches of edible
Christmas tree decorations, 12 of each type, using biscuits. The technical
challenge, set by Mary, tasked the bakers to make a [choux](/wiki/Choux
"Choux") [wreath](/wiki/Wreath "Wreath") consisting of 36 choux buns, filled
and decorated festively with chocolate. For the showstopper challenge, the
bakers were required to make a Christmas scene cake, which must be at least
three tiers.

(24 edible biscuit [tree decorations](/wiki/Christmas_ornament "Christmas ornament")) | Technical  
([choux](/wiki/Choux "Choux") [wreath](/wiki/Wreath "Wreath")) | Showstopper  
(Christmas scene cake)  
---|---|---|---  
Ali | Rose & Fennel [Henna](/wiki/Henna "Henna")-Inspired Biscuits and Date & Orange [Ma'amoul](/wiki/Ma%27amoul "Ma'amoul") Bauble Biscuits | 1st | Celebration of [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") Cake  
Cathryn | Chocolate Peppermint [Candy Canes](/wiki/Candy_Canes "Candy Canes") and Clementine, Cranberry & Rosemary [Holly](/wiki/Holly "Holly") Leaf Biscuits | 2nd | Our [Christmas Eve](/wiki/Christmas_Eve "Christmas Eve")  
Mary-Anne | [Christmas Pudding](/wiki/Christmas_Pudding "Christmas Pudding") and Christmas [Wreath](/wiki/Wreath "Wreath") Biscuits | 3rd | My Christmas Cakey Bakey  
Norman | Orange & Cinnamon Dufrickies and Whisky Shortbread Ding Dangs | 4th | Gâteau De [Joyeux Noël](/wiki/Joyeux_No%C3%ABl "Joyeux Noël")  
  
### Episode
2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Episode 2")]

The bakers were tasked to make 24 savoury Christmas canapés, 12 of two types
in the signature challenge. The technical challenge was set by Paul, in which
the bakers were tasked of baking a Kanellängd, a spiced Scandinavian
celebratory Christmas loaf with the meaning of "[cinnamon](/wiki/Cinnamon
"Cinnamon") length". For the showstopper challenge, the bakers were required
to make 36 sweet Christmas miniatures, 12 each of three types, arranged as a
celebratory centerpiece.

##
Controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Controversies")]

Before the series had begun, some viewers complained of the "gendered" icing
in preview pictures of the bakers. In the promo shots of the bakers, the male
bakers were given blue icing while the female bakers were given pink icing,
whereas the previous year, every baker was given the same colour
regardless.[35][36][37] As a result, the BBC altered the colouring of the
icing.[38]

##
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off_\(series_7\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Ratings")]

The opening episode had an average viewing figure of 10.4 million according to
overnight ratings, an improvement over the figure of 9.3 million for the
corresponding episode in 2015. This made it the most watched TV show of 2016
so far, with the official figure also making it the most watched TV show since
the 2015 Bake Off Final.[39] Its run on the BBC ended with an average
overnight viewing figure of 14 million for the final, peaking at 14.8 million,
which is a record for the show.[40] The series dominated the list of most-
watched programmes in 2016, with nine of the top ten being episodes of the
show.[41] Its finale was watched by 15.9 million viewers (7 days cumulative
figure), the most popular of the year.[42]
